    73. 73
      Umemura, K.; Kondo, K.; Ikeda, Y.; Kobayashi, T.; Urata, Y.; Nakashima, M. Pharmacokinetics and safety of JTP-4819, a novel specific orally active prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, in healthy male volunteers Br. J. Clin. Pharmacol. 1997, 43, 613– 618
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      73
      Pharmacokinetics and safety of JTP-4819, a novel specific orally active prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, in healthy male volunteers
      Umemura, K.; Kondo, K.; Ikeda, Y.; Kobayashi, T.; Urata, Y.; Nakashima, M.
      British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology (1997), 43 (6), 613-618CODEN: BCPHBM; ISSN:0306-5251. (Blackwell)
      In order to investigate the pharmacokinetics and safety profile of JTP-4819, (-)-(2S)-1-benzylaminocarbonyl-[(2S)-2-glycoloylpyrrolidinyl]-2-pyrrolidinecarboxamide, a novel specific orally active prolyl endopeptidase (PEP) inhibitor, JTP-4819 was given orally to 28 healthy male volunteers at single doses of 30 mg (n=6), 60 mg (n=6), 120 mg (n=6) and placebo (n=3) and multiple doses of 60 mg three times daily (n=5) and placebo (n=2) for 7 days to investigate its safety and pharmacokinetics following a preliminary safety evaluation of 3, 10 and 30 mg doses in six healthy volunteers. With the single dose of 60 mg, a cross-over study was conducted to examine the effect of food on the bioavailability of the drug. The concns. of JTP-4819 in plasma and urine were detd. by electrospray ionization-liq. chromatog./mass spectrometry (ESI-LC/MS) method. In the multiple-dose study, the cholinesterase activity was gradually increased and reached above the normal range on days 4 to 8 in all five subjects given JTP-4819 and gradually returned to normal range after completion of dosing. The elevation of plasma cholinesterase activity was considered to be an action of JTP-4819, but this remains to be verified. There were no other abnormal findings in objective symptoms and lab. findings including blood pressure, heart rate, ECG, body temp., hematol., blood chem. and urinalysis. The Cmax of JTP-4819 at 30, 60 and 120 mg in fasting state were 474, 887 and 1649 ng mL-1, resp., at 1 h after administration, and the t1/2 was about 2 h. AUC increased in proportion to the given doses. The cumulative urinary recoveries within 24 h were approx. 66%. Cmax, AUC, t1/2 and urinary recovery were not affected by food intake. In the multiple-dose study, there was no drug accumulation trend in plasma. These results indicate that JTP-4819 has acceptable pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetics profiles for clin. use without any serious adverse events as we verified in healthy young male volunteers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2sXks1Sjsrg%253D&md5=9962d7b12c0d6cbc5c8098bcc6f8688c
    74. 74
      Morain, P.; Robin, J. L.; De Nanteuil, G.; Jochemsen, R.; Heidet, V.; Guez, D. Pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic profile of S 17092, a new orally active prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, in elderly healthy volunteers. A phase I study Br. J. Clin. Pharmacol. 2000, 50, 350– 359
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      74
      Pharmacodynamic and pharmacokinetic profile of S 17092, a new orally active prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, in elderly healthy volunteers. A phase I study
      Morain, P.; Robin, J. L.; De Nanteuil, G.; Jochemsen, R.; Heidet, V.; Guez, D.
      British Journal of Clinical Pharmacology (2000), 50 (4), 350-359CODEN: BCPHBM; ISSN:0306-5251. (Blackwell Science Ltd.)
      This was a double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, single- and multiple-dose study in elderly healthy male and female volunteers. Four doses of S 17092 were investigated in sequential order: 100, 400, 800 and 1200 mg. Each dose was administered orally once a day as single administration and then, after a 1-wk washout period, for 7 days. Pharmacodynamics were assessed by measurement of plasma prolyl endopeptidase (PEP) activity, quant. EEG and psychometric tests. S 17092 concns. in plasma were quantified by HPLC with tandem mass-spectrometric detection. PEP activity in plasma was dose-dependently inhibited both after administration of a single dose and after repeated doses of S 17092. The mean maximal inhibition was obtained within 0.5-2 h after administration, and inhibition lasted ≥12 h. S 17092 appeared to be a centrally active substance, as it induced modifications in the EEG compared with placebo. S 17092 at 100 mg acutely increased the alpha band 4 h and 8 h after a single administration. When administered repeatedly for 7 days S 17092 did not appear to induce significant or lasting central nervous system effects. In psychometric tests, response times in the numeric working memory were reduced compared with placebo, following the 800-mg dose. There were some beneficial residual effects of the 1200-mg dose on day 13: delayed word recall and word recognition sensitivity improved compared with the declines noted under placebo. Maximum plasma drug concn. and area under the curve increased in proportion to the dose. The terminal half-life ranged 9-31 h on day 1 and 7-18 h on day 14. A high interindividual variability was obsd. at all doses tested. S 17092 was well tolerated, with no clin. significant changes in lab. or phys. parameters at any dose. Thus, S 17092 had a potent, dose-dependent inhibitory effect on plasma PEP, increased the alpha band of the EEG at the 100-mg dose and improved performance in 2 verbal memory tests at the 1200-mg dose, while there was disruption of the vigilance task. These results in elderly healthy subjects indicated that S 17092 is suitable for once-daily administration without any serious adverse events.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXnvV2gsb0%253D&md5=dda6df262d50f4b669291963ea192fd7
    75. 75
      Szeltner, Z.; Rea, D.; Renner, V.; Fulop, V.; Polgar, L. Electrostatic effects and binding determinants in the catalysis of prolyl oligopeptidase. Site specific mutagenesis at the oxyanion binding site J. Biol. Chem. 2002, 277, 42613– 42622
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      75
      Electrostatic Effects and Binding Determinants in the Catalysis of Prolyl Oligopeptidase. Site-specific mutagenesis at the oxyanion binding site
      Szeltner, Zoltan; Rea, Dean; Renner, Veronika; Fulop, Vilmos; Polgar, Laszlo
      Journal of Biological Chemistry (2002), 277 (45), 42613-42622CODEN: JBCHA3; ISSN:0021-9258. (American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology)
      Prolyl oligopeptidase, a member of a new family of serine peptidases, plays an important role in memory disorders. Earlier X-ray crystallog. investigations indicated that stabilization of the tetrahedral transition state of the reaction involved hydrogen bond formation between the oxyanion of the tetrahedral intermediate and the OH group of Tyr473. The contribution of the OH group was tested with the Y473F variant using various substrates. The charged succinyl-Gly-Pro-4-nitroanilide was hydrolyzed with a much lower kcat/Km compared with the neutral benzyloxycarbonyl-G1y-Pro-2-naphthylamide, although the binding modes of the two substrates were similar, as shown by X-ray crystallog. This suggested that electrostatic interactions between Arg643 and the succinyl group competed with the productive binding mechanism. Unlike most enzyme reactions, catalysis by the wild-type enzyme exhibited pos. activation entropy. In contrast, the activation entropy for the Y473F variant was neg., suggesting that the tyrosine OH group is involved in stabilizing both the transition state and the water shell at the active site. Importantly, Tyr473 is also implicated in the formation of the enzyme-substrate complex. The nonlinear Arrhenius plot suggested a greater significance of the oxyanion binding site at physiol. temp. The results indicated that Tyr473 was more needed at high pH, at high temp., and with charged substrates exhibiting "internally competitive inhibition".
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38Xos1ensbs%253D&md5=9e9d3f86c15febc85929ef55134ed6e5
    76. 76
      Szeltner, Z.; Rea, D.; Juhasz, T.; Renner, V.; Mucsi, Z.; Orosz, G.; Fulop, V.; Polgar, L. Substrate-dependent competency of the catalytic triad of prolyl oligopeptidase J. Biol. Chem. 2002, 277, 44597– 605
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.

      Szeltner, Z.; Rea, D.; Renner, V.; Juliano, L.; Fulop, V.; Polgar, L. Electrostatic environment at the active site of prolyl oligopeptidase is highly influential during substrate binding J. Biol. Chem. 2003, 278, 48786– 48793
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    78. 78
      Shan, L.; Mathews, I. I.; Khosla, C. Structural and mechanistic analysis of two prolyl endopeptidases: role of interdomain dynamics in catalysis and specificity Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U.S.A. 2005, 102, 3599– 604
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      78
      Structural and mechanistic analysis of two prolyl endopeptidases: role of interdomain dynamics in catalysis and specificity
      Shan, Lu; Mathews, Irimpan I.; Khosla, Chaitan
      Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America (2005), 102 (10), 3599-3604CODEN: PNASA6; ISSN:0027-8424. (National Academy of Sciences)
      Prolyl endopeptidases (PEPs) are a unique class of serine proteases with considerable therapeutic potential for the treatment of celiac sprue. The crystal structures of two didomain PEPs have been solved in alternative configurations, thereby providing insights into the mode of action of these enzymes. The structure of the Sphingomonas capsulata PEP, solved and refined to 1.8-Å resoln., revealed an open configuration of the active site. In contrast, the inhibitor-bound PEP from Myxococcus xanthus was crystd. (1.5-Å resoln.) in a closed form. Comparative anal. of the two structures highlights a crit. role for the domain interface in regulating interdomain dynamics and substrate specificity. Structure-based mutagenesis of the M. xanthus PEP confirms an important role for several interfacial residues. A salt bridge between Arg-572 and Asp-196/Glu-197 appears to act as a latch for opening or closing the didomain enzyme, and Arg-572 and Ile-575 may also help secure the incoming peptide substrate to the open form of the enzyme. Arg-618 and Asp-145 are responsible for anchoring the invariant proline residue in the active site of this postproline-cleaving enzyme. A model is proposed for the docking of a representative substrate PQPQLPYPQPQLP in the active site, where the N-terminal substrate residues interact extensively with the catalytic domain, and the C-terminal residues stretch into the propeller domain. Given the promise of the M. xanthus PEP as an oral therapeutic enzyme for treating celiac sprue, our results provide a strong foundation for further optimization of the PEP's clin. useful features.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXisVOgs7g%253D&md5=036c8baffe44c24a1b01696116a6008b

      [ACS Full Text ], Google Scholar

    81. 81
      Berger, Y.; Bernasconi, C. C.; Schmitt, F.; Neier, R.; Juillerat-Jeanneret, L. Determination of intracellular prolyl/glycyl proteases in intact living human cells and protoporphyrin IX production as a reporter system Chem. Biol. 2005, 12, 867– 872
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      81
      Determination of Intracellular Prolyl/Glycyl Proteases in Intact Living Human Cells and Protoporphyrin IX Production as a Reporter System
      Berger, Yann; Chapuis Bernasconi, Catherine; Schmitt, Frederic; Neier, Reinhard; Juillerat-Jeanneret, Lucienne
      Chemistry & Biology (Cambridge, MA, United States) (2005), 12 (8), 867-872CODEN: CBOLE2; ISSN:1074-5521. (Cell Press)
      Summary: The detn. of enzyme activity or inhibition in intact living cells is a problem in the development of inhibitors for intracellular proteases. The prodn. of fluorescent protoporphyrin IX (PpIX) from the nonfluorescent (N)-Gly/Pro-5-aminolevulinic acid (ALA) substrates was used to evaluate the prolyl/glycyl-specific dipeptidylpeptidase IV (DPPIV)-like and prolyloligopeptidase (POP)-like activities of human cells. The results demonstrated that whereas POP-like activity could be attributed to the actual POP, the DPPIV-like activity could be related to actual DPPIV only in one colon cell line. In the other breast and colon cell lines, DPPIV-like activity was intracellular and displayed by other prolyl-specific aminopeptidases. Our expts. also demonstrated the involvement of glycyl-specific proteases in the processing of ALA precursors. These observations have important consequences for the development and evaluation of selective inhibitors for these enzymes.

      A review with 101 refs. primarily concerned with synthetic and low mol. wt. prolyl endopeptidase inhibitors.

    83. 83
      Wilk, S.; Orlowski, M. Inhibition of rabbit brain prolyl endopeptidase by N-benzyloxycarbonyl-prolyl-prolinal, a transition state aldehyde inhibitor J. Neurochem. 1983, 41, 69– 75
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      83
      Inhibition of rabbit brain prolyl endopeptidase by N-benzyloxycarbonyl-prolyl-prolinal, a transition state aldehyde inhibitor
      Wilk, Sherwin; Orlowski, Marian
      Journal of Neurochemistry (1983), 41 (1), 69-75CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042.
      Benzyloxycarbonyl-prolyl-prolinal was synthesized as a potential transition state analog inhibitor of rabbit brain prolyl endopeptidase. The aldehyde was a remarkably potent inhibitor with a Ki of 14 nM. This Ki is >3000 times lower than that of the corresponding acid or alc. By analogy with other transition state inhibitors, it can be assumed that binding of the prolinal residue to the S1 subsite and the formation of a hemiacetal with the active serine of the enzyme greatly contribute to the potency of inhibition. The specificity of the inhibitor is indicated by the finding that a variety of proteases were not affected at concns. 150 times greater than the Ki for prolyl endopeptidase. Evidently, benzyloxycarbonyl-prolyl-prolinal is a specific and potent inhibitor of prolyl endopeptidase and consequently it should be of value in vivo studies on the physiol. role of the enzyme.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3sXltVWnsb0%253D&md5=0b6af2671b1011b26daa2e1f280b071f
    84. 84
      Bakker, A. V.; Jung, S.; Spencer, R. W.; Vinick, F. J.; Faraci, W. S. Slow tight-binding inhibition of prolyl endopeptidase by benzyloxycarbonyl-prolyl-prolinal Biochem. J. 1990, 271, 559– 562
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      84
      Slow tight-binding inhibition of prolyl endopeptidase by benzyloxycarbonyl-prolyl-prolinal
      Bakker, Alice V.; Jung, Stanley; Spencer, Robin W.; Vinick, Fredric J.; Faraci, W. Stephen
      Biochemical Journal (1990), 271 (2), 559-62CODEN: BIJOAK; ISSN:0264-6021.
      Z-Prolyl-prolinal is a slow-binding inhibitor of mouse brain prolyl endopeptidase with Ki 0.35 nM. Kinetic anal. indicates that the mechanism is a simple, but slow, reversible equil. between free and bound enzyme (E + I ↹ EI) with rate consts. for assocn. (kon) and dissocn. (koff) of 1.6 × 105 M-1 s-1 and ∼ 4 × 10-5 s-1, resp. Slow-binding inhibition is dependent on the presence of the aldehyde group since the alc. (Z-prolyl-prolinol) is a rapid and 50,000-fold poorer inhibitor (Ki 19 μM). Prolyl endopeptidase from human brain is also inhibited by Z-prolyl-prolinal with kinetics similar to those of the mouse brain enzyme.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3MXhvF2rsQ%253D%253D&md5=f41366825536a4c0f6f386217aad0f23

    86. 86
      Li, J.; Wilk, E.; Wilk, S. Inhibition of prolyl oligopeptidase by Fmoc-aminoacylpyrrolidine-2-nitriles J. Neurochem. 1996, 66, 2105– 2112
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      86
      Inhibition of prolyl oligopeptidase by Fmoc-aminoacylpyrrolidine-2-nitriles
      Li, Jingrong; Wilk, Elizabeth; Wilk, Sherwin
      Journal of Neurochemistry (1996), 66 (5), 2105-12CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042. (Lippincott-Raven)
      Prolyl oligopeptidase (EC 3.4.21.26), a widely distributed cytosolic enzyme, cleaves peptidylpropyl peptide and peptidylprolyl amino acid bonds in many neuropeptide substrates. Its action on vasopressin has been proposed as the underlying mechanism accounting for the ability of inhibitors of prolyl oligopeptidase to reverse scopolamine-induced amnesia in rats. Future behavioral studies would be facilitated by the availability of potent inhibitors readily synthesized from common intermediates. A series of Fmoc-aminoacylpyrrolidine-2-nitriles prepd. by a simple two-step synthesis were found to be potent noncompetitive inhibitors of the rabbit brain enzyme. The most potent inhibitors, Fmoc-prolyl-pyrrolidine-2-nitrile and Fmoc-alanyl-pyrrolidine-2-nitrile, each have a Ki of 5 nM. The compds. are cell permeable and stable. They do not inhibit the related enzyme dipeptidyl peptidase IV (EC 3.4.14.5). When administered i.p. to mice, Fmoc-alanyl-pyrrolidine-2-nitrile crosses the blood-brain barrier to inhibit brain prolyl oligopeptidase. The ease of synthesis, potency, efficacy in vivo, stability, and specificity of Fmoc-aminoacylpyrrolidine-2-nitriles may make them inhibitors of choice in studies probing the physiol. significance of prolyl oligopeptidase.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK28XisVSrs7c%253D&md5=b1b929f56f6839a0299fa749e2536aaa

      Yoshimoto, T.; Simmons, W. H.; Kita, T.; Tsuru, D. Post-proline cleaving enzyme from lamb brain J. Biochem. 1981, 90, 325– 334
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      89
      Post-proline cleaving enzyme from lamb brain
      Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Simmons, William H.; Kita, Taizo; Tsuru, Daisuke
      Journal of Biochemistry (1981), 90 (2), 325-34CODEN: JOBIAO; ISSN:0021-924X.
      Postproline endopeptidase (EC 3.4.21.26) (I) was purified 1184-fold from lamb brain. Purified I appeared homogeneous on disc gel and SDS-gel electrophoresis. I was most active at pH 7.0 with carbobenzoxy-Gly-Pro β-naphthylamide as substrate and if catalyzed the hydrolysis of oxytocin, vasopressin, thyrotropin-releasing hormone, substance P, LH-releasing hormone, and angiotensin at the carboxyl side of their proline residues, except for the Pro2-Lys3 bond in substance P. From the results of subsite mapping using synthetic peptides, 5 subsites, S3 to S2', for substrate interaction with I were deduced and high stereospecificity was obsd. at S2, S1, and S1'. The isoelec. point of I was 4.9, and the mol. wts. estd. by gel filtration and SDS-gel electrophoresis were 74,000 and 77,000, resp. I was markedly inhibited by diisopropyl phosphorofluoridate, carbobenzoxy-Gly-Pro chloromethyl ketone, p-chloromercuribenzoate, Hg2+, and Cu2+. These enzymic and chem. properties of I from lamb brain closely resembled those of lamb kidney I, the mol. wt. of which was reevaluated as 74,000.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3MXlsVGrtrg%253D&md5=a72849b35730e8f25c3239b5400d537b
    90. 90
      Yoshimoto, T.; Tsukumo, K.; Takatsuka, N.; Tsuru, D. An inhibitor for post-proline cleaving enzyme; distribution and partial purification from porcine pancreas J. Pharmacobio-Dyn. 1982, 5, 734– 740
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      90
      An inhibitor for post-proline cleaving enzyme; distribution and partial purification from porcine pancreas
      Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Tsukumo, Kenichi; Takatsuka, Naoki; Tsuru, Daisuke
      Journal of Pharmacobio-Dynamics (1982), 5 (9), 734-40CODEN: JOPHDQ; ISSN:0386-846X.
      An inhibitor(s) for post-proline-cleaving enzyme was detected by using a fluorogenic substrate, benzyloxycarbonyl-Gly-Pro-4-methylcoumarinamide, and was found to be distributed widely in rat and porcine organs. The highest inhibitory activity was obsd. in pancreas, and the inhibitor was partially purified from porcine pancreas ext. by heat treatment, chromatogs. on DEAE-Sephadex and Sephadex G-50, and affinity chromatog. on trypsin-Sepharose. This inhibitor was very stable against temp., pH, and TCA treatment. The mol. wt. was estd. to be 6500 by gel filtration. This inhibitor was highly specific for prolyl endopeptidases from mammals and Flavobacterium and inhibited the enzyme competitively. It acted neither on proline-specific exopeptidases such as dipeptidyl aminopeptidase IV, proline aminopeptidase, prolidase, nor usual endopeptidases such as trypsin and α-chymotrypsin.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL3sXjtVahsw%253D%253D&md5=97fa733e28393fb90e4c51e0bc15fa19
    91. 91
      Yoshimoto, T.; Nishimura, T.; Kita, T.; Tsuru, D. Post-proline cleaving enzyme (prolyl endopeptidase) from bovine brain J. Biochem. 1983, 94, 1179– 1190
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      91
      Post-proline cleaving enzyme (prolyl endopeptidase) from bovine brain
      Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Nishimura, Toshiharu; Kita, Taizo; Tsuru, Daisuke
      Journal of Biochemistry (1983), 94 (4), 1179-90CODEN: JOBIAO; ISSN:0021-924X.
      A postproline cleaving enzyme (EC 3.4.21.26) (I) was purified ∼3700-fold from an ext. of bovine brain by a series of column chromatogs. on DEAE-Sephadex, hydroxlapatite and p-chloromercuribenzoate-triethylenetetramine-Sepharose, and gel filtration on Sephadex G-200 with N-carbobenzoxy-Gly-Pro-β-naphthylamide (Z-Gly-Pro-2-NNap), TRH, and oxytocin as substrates. Purified I appeared homogeneous as judged by disc gel and SDS-gel electrophoresis. I was most active at pH 7.5 and 7.2 with Z-Gly-Pro-2-NNap and TRH, resp., and hydrolyzed peptide bonds involving Pro-X (X = amino acid, peptide, ester, and amide) bonds of synthetic substrates, oxytocin, vasopressin, neurotensin, substance P, tuftsin, bradykinin, and insulin B chain. However, I was inert toward collagen, gelatin, and casein. I was completely inactivated by diisopropyl phosphorofluoridate, Z-Gly-Pro-chloromethyl ketone, and p-chloromercuribenzoate, whereas it was not inhibited by phenylmethanesulfonyl fluoride or metal chelators. Detn. of the amino acid compn. revealed that I contained 25 half-cystines. Modification of 3 cysteine residues of I by p-chloromercuribenzoate led to complete inactivation. The pI of I was 4.8, and the mol. wt. was estd. to be 76,000 by ultracentrifugal anal. and 75,000-74,000 by both gel filtration and SDS-gel electrophoresis, suggesting that I is present as a monomer. The results indicated that I from bovine brain is very similar to those previously purified from lamb brain and kidney in its enzymic properties, substrate specificity, and physicochem. properties, in sharp contrast with the results obtained by S. S. Tate (1981), who reported that the bovine brain I was inert toward oxytocin, vasopressin, and bradykinin.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL2cXisFKq&md5=c2ac9baa56dc7c67e7d351c24b01019d
    92. 92
      Yoshimoto, T.; Kado, K.; Matsubara, F.; Koriyama, N.; Kaneto, H.; Tsuru, D. Specific inhibitors for prolyl endopeptidase and their anti-amnesic effect J. Pharmacobio-Dyn. 1987, 10, 730– 735
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      92
      Specific inhibitors for prolyl endopeptidase and their antiamnesic effect
      Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Kado, Kunio; Matsubara, Futoshi; Koriyama, Nobuhiro; Kaneto, Hiroshi; Tsuru, Daisuke
      Journal of Pharmacobio-Dynamics (1987), 10 (12), 730-5CODEN: JOPHDQ; ISSN:0386-846X.
      Ten peptides and peptide derivs. were tested for their inhibitory effect on prolyl endopeptidase and possible properties as antiamnesic agents. Among the compds. tested, Z-Gly-Pro-CH2Cl, Z-Val-prolinal, Boc-Pro-prolinal, Z-Pro-prolinal, aniracetam, and pramiracetam inhibited the enzyme with Ki values in the nanomolar-to-micromolar range; the effect of the prolinal-contg. derivs. was specific for prolyl endopeptidase. Z-Pro-prolinal was the most effective inhibitor in vitro (Ki = 5 nM) and in vivo (50-70% inhibition in various rat organs at 1 μmol/animal i.p.). Regional differences were obsd. in the effect of the in the mesencephalon, followed by the striatum, cerebellum, hippocampus, hypothalamus; they were inactive in the cortex and medulla oblongata. In the passive avoidance learning test in rats, pretreatment with Z-Pro-prolinal (1 μmol, i.p.) prevented the induction of amnesia by scopolamine. Z-Val-prolinal, Z-Pyr-prolinal and Z-Gly-Pro-CH2Cl were also effective in the retention test at 24 and 48 h after the training trial. The antiamnesic effect of these compds. was approx. parallel to the in vitro inhibitory activities on prolyl endopeptidase. The inhibitors may exhibit their antiamnesic effect through regulation of enzyme activity in the brain.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1cXht1Cgt7w%253D&md5=670fd8e3d6d381596ee45ea07f889171
    93. 93
      Tsuru, D.; Yoshimoto, T.; Koriyama, N.; Furukawa, S. Thiazolidine derivatives as potent inhibitors specific for prolyl endopeptidase J. Biochem. 1988, 104, 580– 586
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      93
      Thiazolidine derivatives as potent inhibitors specific for prolyl endopeptidase
      Tsuru, Daisuke; Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Koriyama, Nobuhiro; Furukawa, Sunao
      Journal of Biochemistry (1988), 104 (4), 580-6CODEN: JOBIAO; ISSN:0021-924X.
      A series of N-blocked L-proline-contg. compds. and their derivs. were prepd. Their inhibitory activities for prolyl endopeptidase from bovine brain were examd. and compared with that of N-benzoyloxycarbonyl-L-prolyl-L-prolinal, which is the most effective enzyme inhibitor hitherto reported. Introduction of a S atom into pyrrolidine ring quite effectively increased the inhibitory activity: replacement of pyrrolidine with thiazolidine or thiazolidine aldehyde (thioprolinal) and conversion of L-proline to L-thioproline residue resulted in increase in the inhibitory activity. Thus, N-benzyloxycarbonyl-L-thiopropyl-thiazolidine (Z-Thioprothiazolidine) and Z-L-Thiopro-L-thioprolinal showed Ki values of 0.36 and 0.01 nM, resp., for prolyl endopeptidase from bovine brain; both values were significantly lower than that of Z-Pro-prolinal (Ki 3.7 nM).
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL1MXitVentg%253D%253D&md5=ae68b17e67cf030189c4377821614327
    94. 94
      Yoshimoto, T.; Tsuru, D.; Yamamoto, N.; Ikezawa, R.; Furukawa, S. Structure activity relationship of inhibitors specific for prolyl endopeptidase Agric. Biol. Chem. 1991, 55, 37– 43
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      94
      Structure activity relationship of inhibitors specific for prolyl endopeptidase
      Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Tsuru, Daisuke; Yamamoto, Naoko; Ikezawa, Ryuhei; Furukawa, Sunao
      Agricultural and Biological Chemistry (1991), 55 (1), 37-43CODEN: ABCHA6; ISSN:0002-1369.
      Structural requirements of N-blocked L-proline derivs. as specific inhibitors for prolyl endopeptidase were investigated using a series of substrate analogs. Replacement of L-proline by its D-isomer markedly reduced the inhibition. Introduction of a S atom in proline and/or in the penultimate pyrrolidine rings significantly increased the inhibition, but the introduction of an O atom rather diminished the activity. A peptide linkage (acid-amide bond) between the proline and the pyrrolidine ring was also required to keep the inhibitory activity. A benzyloxycarbonyl group was most effective as an N-blocked component of the inhibitors.

      Stöckel-Maschek, A.; Mrestani-Klaus, C.; Stiebitz, B.; Demuth, H. U.; Neubert, K. Thioxo amino acid pyrrolidides and thiazolidides: new inhibitors of proline specific peptidases Biochim. Biophys. Acta, Protein Struct. Mol. Enzymol. 2000, 1479, 15– 31
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      105
      Thioxo amino acid pyrrolidides and thiazolidides: new inhibitors of proline specific peptidases
      Stockel-Maschek, A.; Mrestani-Klaus, C.; Stiebitz, B.; Demuth, H.-U.; Neubert, K.
      Biochimica et Biophysica Acta, Protein Structure and Molecular Enzymology (2000), 1479 (1-2), 15-31CODEN: BBAEDZ; ISSN:0167-4838. (Elsevier B.V.)
      Aminopeptidase P (APP), dipeptidyl peptidase II (DP II), dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DP IV) and prolyl oligopeptidase (POP) are proline specific peptidases. Hence, they are able to cleave peptide bonds contg. the imino acid proline. Amino acid pyrrolidides (Pyrr) and thiazolidides (Thia) are well-known product analog inhibitors of DP IV and POP. For the first time we describe the influence of a thioxo amide bond, incorporated into these compds., on the inhibition of the proline specific peptidases. Taking into account the substrate specificity of these peptidases, we have synthesized Xaa-ψ[CS-N]-Pyrr and Xaa-ψ[CS-N]-Thia of the amino acids Ala, Phe, Val and Ile. The inhibition consts. were detd. for the above mentioned proline specific peptidases isolated from different sources. As a result, the serine proteases DP II, DP IV and POP were inhibited competitively, whereas metal-dependent APP displayed a linear mixed-type inhibition with inhibition consts. up to 10-4 M. Thioxylation of Xaa-Pyrr and Xaa-Thia led to a slight decrease of inhibition of DP IV and POP compared to Xaa-Pyrr and Xaa-Thia, though the inhibition consts. were still in the range up to 10-7 M. As Xaa-Thia exist as two isomers, we investigated isomer specific inhibition with regard to DP IV. Thus, our studies have revealed that DP IV was only inhibited by the Z isomer of the Xaa-ψ[CS-N]-Thia. For the first time, Xaa-Pyrr and Xaa-Thia were characterized as inhibitors of DP II with inhibition consts. in the micromolar range. In contrast to DP IV inhibition, the Xaa-ψ[CS-N]-Pyrr and Xaa-ψ[CS-N]-Thia have proven to be more potent inhibitors of DP II than the corresponding Xaa-Pyrr and Xaa-Thia. Thus, these Xaa-ψ[CS-N]-Thia are new potent inhibitors esp. suitable for DP II with Ki values ranging in the upper nanomolar concn.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXktV2qtrk%253D&md5=e89e9612a50f14277a2c9c967043abe7
    106. 106

    113. 113
      Toide, K.; Iwamoto, Y.; Fujiwara, T.; Abe, H. JTP-4819: a novel prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor with potential as a cognitive enhancer J. Pharmacol. Exp. Ther. 1995, 274, 1370– 1378
      [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      113
      JTP-4819: a novel prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor with potential as a cognitive enhancer
      Toide, Katsuo; Iwamoto, Yohko; Fujiwara, Takao; Abe, Hiroyuki
      Journal of Pharmacology and Experimental Therapeutics (1995), 274 (3), 1370-8CODEN: JPETAB; ISSN:0022-3565. (Williams & Wilkins)
      JTP-4819 {(S)-2-[[(S)-2-(hydroxyacetyl)-1-pyrrolidinyl]carbonyl]-N-(phenylmethyl)-1-pyrrolidinecarboxamide} is a potent (IC50: 0.83 ± 0.09 nM in rat brain supernatant; 5.43 ± 0.81 nM in Flavobacterium meningosepticum) and specific inhibitor of prolyl endopeptidase (PEP). JTP-4819 (3 mg/kg p.o.) exhibited a strong and durable ex vivo inhibitory effect on PEP in various regions of the rat brain. In addn., JTP-4819 inhibited the degrdn. of substance P, arginine-vasopressin, TSH-releasing hormone, neurotensin, oxytocin, bradykinin, and angiotensin II by purified PEP with IC50 values of 9.6, 13.9, 10.7, 14.0, 4.5, 7.6 and 10.6 nM, resp. In the one-trial passive avoidance test in rats with scopolamine-induced amnesia, JTP-4819 significantly prolonged the retention time when administered orally at doses of 1 and 3 mg/kg 1 h before acquisition or at 3 and 10 mg/kg 1 h before retention. In addn., coadministration of JTP-4819 and substance P, arginine-vasopressin or TSH-releasing hormone (at doses at which each drug alone did not prolong the retention time) improved the retention time of rats with scopolamine-induced amnesia. Microdialysis studies demonstrated that JTP-4819 caused a significant increase in ACh release in the frontal cortex and hippocampus of young rats at oral doses of 1 and 3 mg/kg, as well as in both brain regions of aged rats at a dose of 3 mg/kg. These results indicate that JTP-4819 potentiates neuropeptide functions by inhibiting PEP, that it activates cholinergic transmission and that it enhances learning and memory.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXot1yjtr0%253D&md5=60d0ebea999d2fceb0c751d613c3bbb0
    114. 114
      Toide, K.; Okamiya, K.; Iwamoto, Y.; Kato, T. Effect of a novel prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, JTP-4819, on prolyl endopeptidase activity and substance P- and arginine-vasopressin-like immunoreactivity in the brains of aged rats J. Neurochem. 1995, 65, 234– 240
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      114
      Effect of a novel prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, JTP-4819, on prolyl endopeptidase activity and substance P- and arginine-vasopressin-like immunoreactivity in the brains of aged rats
      Toide, Katsuo; Okamiya, Kazuhiro; Iwamato, Yohko; Kato, Takeshi
      Journal of Neurochemistry (1995), 65 (1), 234-40CODEN: JONRA9; ISSN:0022-3042. (Raven)
      The effect of a novel prolyl endopeptidase (PEP) inhibitor, (S)-2-[[(S)-2-(hydroxyacetyl)-1-pyrrolidinyl]carbonyl]-N-(phenylmethyl)-1-pyrrolidinylcarboxamide (JTP-4819), on the PEP activity in the brain and on the contents of substance P (SP)- and arginine-vasopressin (AVP)-like immunoreactivity (LI) in the cerebral cortex and hippocampus of young and aged rats were investigated using enzyme immunoassay. JTP-4819 exhibited a concn.-dependent in vitro inhibitory action on PEP activity in the brains of both young and aged rats, with IC50 values of ∼0.7, and 0.8 nM, resp. A single dose of JTP-4819 (3 mg/kg, p.o.) increased the SPLI content in the cerebral cortex but not the hippocampus of aged rats (23-24 mo old). In addn., repeated administration of JTP-4819 (1 mg/kg, p.o, for 21 days) increased the SPLI content in the cerebral cortex and restored the SPLI content in the hippocampus, which had decreased with aging. In contrast, single (1 mg/kg, p.o.) and repeated (1 mg/kg, p.o., for 21 days) administration of JTP-4819 only tended to increase the AVPLI content of the hippocampus and cerebral cortex in aged rats, resp. These results indicate that JTP-4819 increases the cerebral and hippocampal SPLI content in aged rats by inhibiting the action of PEP.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2MXmsVCjtLc%253D&md5=352076c69cb5b5a923eed05702760118
    115. 115
      Toide, K.; Fujiwara, T.; Iwamoto, Y.; Shinoda, M.; Okamiya, K.; Kato, T. Effect of a novel prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, JTP-4819, on neuropeptide metabolism in the rat brain Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Arch. Pharmacol. 1996, 353, 355– 362
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      115
      Effect of a novel prolyl endopeptidase inhibitor, JTP-4819, on neuropeptide metabolism in the rat brain
      Toide, Katsuo; Fujiwara, Takako; Iwamoto, Yohko; Shinoda, Masahiko; Okamiya, Kazuhiro; Kato, Takeshi
      Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Archives of Pharmacology (1996), 353 (3), 355-62CODEN: NSAPCC; ISSN:0028-1298. (Springer)
      The effect of a novel prolyl endopeptidase (PEP) inhibitor, (S)-2-[[(S)-2-(hydroxyacetyl)-1-pyrrolidinyl] carbonyl]-N-(phenylmethyl)-1-pyrrolidinecarboxamide (JTP-4819), on neuropeptide metab. was investigated in the rat brain. JTP-4819 exhibited a strong in vitro inhibitory effect on cortical and hippocampal PEP activity, with the IC50 values being approx. 0.58 ± 0.02 and 0.06 nM, resp. JTP-4819 also inhibited the in vitro degrdn. of substance P (SP), arginine-vasopressin (AVP), and TSH-releasing hormone (TRH) by rat brain supernatants, with the IC50 values being resp. 3.4, 2.1, and 1.4 nM in the cerebral cortex and 3.3, 2.8, and 1.9 nM in the hippocampus. Oral administration of JTP-4819 at doses of 1 and 3 mg/kg increased SP-like immunoreactivity (LI) and AVP-LI in the cerebral cortex. JTP-4819 also increased hippocampal SP-LI and AVP-LI at doses of 1 and 3 mg/kg, as well as hippocampal TRH-LI at a dose of 3 mg/kg. These findings suggest that JTP-4819 inhibited the degrdn. of SP, AVP, and TRH in the rat brain secondary to the inhibition of PEP, and thus increased cortical and hippocampal SP-LI and AVP-LI as well as hippocampal TRH-LI.

    131. 131
      Atack, J. R.; Suman-Chauhan, N.; Dawson, G.; Kulagowski, J. J. In vitro and in vivo inhibition of prolyl endopeptidase Eur. J. Pharmacol. 1991, 205, 157– 163
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      131
      In vitro and in vivo inhibition of prolyl endopeptidase
      Atack, John R.; Suman-Chauhan, Nirmala; Dawson, Gerard; Kulagowski, Janusz J.
      European Journal of Pharmacology (1991), 205 (2), 157-63CODEN: EJPHAZ; ISSN:0014-2999.
      Four derivs. of a known prolyl endopeptidase (PEP) inhibitor (N-[N-(phenyl)butyryl-L-propyl]pyrrolidine; SUAM-1221) were synthesized along with the parent compd. All five compds. were relatively potent, competitive inhibitors of rat brain and mouse brain and kidney PEP, with IC50s in the range of 3-27 nM. Ex vivo expts. showed that all compds. penetrated into the CNS and produced inhibition of brain PEP, although inhibition was not as great as in the periphery (kidney PEP). Each compd. had a similar time course of duration, with max. inhibition of brain PEP being achieved within 5-10 min after i.p. administration, with inhibition of brain PEP (up to 20%) still present 6 h after dosing. However, two of the compds., SUAM-1221 and its amine deriv., had ED50s vs. mouse brain PEP (1-3 mg/kg) an order of magnitude less than the other compds. (25-40 mg/kg). Administration of the amine compd. resulted in a significant partial reversal of the deficit in memory performance produced by scopolamine.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38Xns1Wqug%253D%253D&md5=aa8d3da4185fe39f2376f8ac3248dfcb

    133. 133
      Saito, M.; Hashimoto, M.; Kawaguchi, N.; Shibata, H.; Fukami, H.; Tanaka, T.; Higuchi, N. Synthesis and inhibitory activity of acyl-peptidyl-pyrrolidine derivatives toward post-proline cleaving enzyme; a study of subsite specificity J. Enzyme Inhib. 1991, 5, 51– 75
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      133
      Synthesis and inhibitory activity of acyl-peptidyl-pyrrolidine derivatives toward post-proline cleaving enzyme; a study of subsite specificity
      Saito, Masayuki; Hashimoto, Masaki; Kawaguchi, Naoko; Shibata, Hiroshi; Fukami, Harukazu; Tanaka, Takaharu; Higuchi, Naoki
      Journal of Enzyme Inhibition (1991), 5 (1), 51-75CODEN: ENINEG; ISSN:8755-5093.
      Several pyrrolidine derivs. were synthesized and examd. for their inhibitory activity on post-proline cleaving enzymes from Flavobacterium meningosepticum and bovine brain. Almost all of the compds. tested in this study inhibited the activity of both enzymes at low IC50 values, but a specificity difference was obsd. with alkylacyl-peptidyl-pyrrolidine derivs. which strongly inhibited only the bacterial enzyme. The most effective inhibitors had a proline residue on their P2 sites and a substituted or unsubstituted phenoxybutyryl moiety on their P3 sites. Thus, phenoxybutyryl-prolyl-pyrrolidine is the most effective partial structure of the inhibitors. The best inhibitors found were: 4-(4-benzylphenoxy)butyryl-prolyl-pyrrolidine for the bacterial enzyme (IC50, 1.4 nM) and 4-phenylbutyrylthioprolyl-pyrrolidine for the bovine brain enzyme (IC50, 67 nM). In the passive avoidance test, using amnesic rats exptl. induced with scopolamine, the pyrrolidine derivs. which had potent inhibitory activity toward post-proline cleaving enzymes also showed strong anti-amnesic activities at doses of 1-5 mg/kg, i.p.

    141. 141
      Edosada, C. Y.; Quan, C.; Wiesmann, C.; Tran, T.; Sutherlin, D.; Reynolds, M.; Elliott, J. M.; Raab, H.; Fairbrother, W.; Wolf, B. B. Selective inhibition of fibroblast activation protein protease based on dipeptide substrate specificity J. Biol. Chem. 2006, 281, 7437– 44

    142. 142
      Lawandi, J.; Toumieux, S.; Seyer, V.; Campbell, P.; Thielges, S.; Juillerat-Jeanneret, L.; Moitessier, N. Constrained peptidomimetics reveal detailed geometric requirements of covalent prolyl oligopeptidase inhibitors J. Med. Chem. 2009, 52, 6672– 6684
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      142
      Constrained peptidomimetics reveal detailed geometric requirements of covalent prolyl oligopeptidase inhibitors
      Lawandi, Janice; Toumieux, Sylvestre; Seyer, Valentine; Campbell, Philip; Thielges, Sabine; Juillerat-Jeanneret, Lucienne; Moitessier, Nicolas
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 52 (21), 6672-6684CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      Prolyl oligopeptidases cleave peptides on the carboxy side of internal proline residues and their inhibition has potential in the treatment of human brain disorders. Using our docking program FITTED, we have designed a series of constrained covalent inhibitors, built from a series of bicyclic scaffolds, to study the optimal shape required for these small mols. These structures bear nitrile functional groups that we predicted to covalently bind to the catalytic serine of the enzyme. Synthesis and biol. assays using human brain-derived astrocytic cells and endothelial cells and human fibroblasts revealed that these compds. act as selective inhibitors of prolyl oligopeptidase activity compared to prolyl-dipeptidyl-aminopeptidase activity, are able to penetrate the cells and inhibit intracellular activities in intact living cells. This integrated computational and exptl. study shed light on the binding mode of inhibitors in the enzyme active site and will guide the design of future drug-like mols.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXht1GgsLjI&md5=45e3fa6cc2888764519936595561d6e0
    143. 143
      Aqvist, J.; Luzhkov, V. B.; Brandsdal, B. O. Ligand binding affinities from MD simulations Acc. Chem. Res. 2002, 35, 358– 365
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      143
      Ligand binding affinities from MD simulations
      Aqvist Johan; Luzhkov Victor B; Brandsdal Bjorn O
      Accounts of chemical research (2002), 35 (6), 358-65 ISSN:0001-4842.
      Simplified free energy calculations based on force field energy estimates of ligand-receptor interactions and thermal conformational sampling have emerged as a useful tool in structure-based ligand design. Here we give an overview of the linear interaction energy (LIE) method for calculating ligand binding free energies from molecular dynamics simulations. A notable feature is that the binding energetics can be predicted by considering only the intermolecular interactions of the ligand in the associated and dissociated states. The approximations behind this approach are examined, and different parametrizations of the model are discussed. LIE-type methods appear particularly promising for computational "lead optimization". Recent applications to protein-protein interactions and ion channel blocking are also discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD38zis1yhtA%253D%253D&md5=97788adac10bb978904c376299087520
    144. 144
      Aqvist, J.; Medina, C.; Samuelsson, J. E. A new method for predicting binding affinity in computer-aided drug design Protein Eng. 1994, 7, 385– 391
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      144
      A new method for predicting binding affinity in computer-aided drug design
      Aqvist J; Medina C; Samuelsson J E
      Protein engineering (1994), 7 (3), 385-91 ISSN:0269-2139.
      A new semi-empirical method for calculating free energies of binding from molecular dynamics (MD) simulations is presented. It is based on standard thermodynamic cycles and on a linear approximation of polar and non-polar free energy contributions from the corresponding MD averages. The method is tested on a set of endothiapepsin inhibitors and found to give accurate results both for absolute as well as relative free energies.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADyaK2c3jtlSnsw%253D%253D&md5=c45572201328309d4fc849844d1c3b71
    145. 145
      Sirviö, J.; Lehtimäki, T. Prolyl Oligopeptidase Inhibitors Ameliorating Recovery from Brain Trauma. WO 2005/002624, 2005.
      Google Scholar
      There is no corresponding record for this reference.
    146. 146
      Juillerat-Jeanneret, L.; Schmitt, F. Chemical modification of therapeutic drugs or drug vector systems to achieve targeted therapy: looking for the grail Med. Res. Rev. 2007, 27, 574– 590
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      146
      Chemical modification of therapeutic drugs of drug vector systems to achieve targeted therapy: looking for the grail
      Juillerat-Jeanneret, L.; Schmitt, F.
      Medicinal Research Reviews (2007), 27 (4), 574-590CODEN: MRREDD; ISSN:0198-6325. (John Wiley & Sons, Inc.)
      A review. Most therapeutic drugs distribute to the whole body, which results in general toxicity and poor acceptance of the treatments by patients. The targeted delivery of chemotherapeutics to defined cells, either stromal or cancer cells in cancer lesions, or defined inflammatory cells in immunol. disorders, is one of the main challenges and a very active field of research in the development of treatment strategies to minimize side-effects of drugs. Disease-assocd. cells express mols., including proteases, receptors, or adhesion mols., that are different or differently expressed than their normal counterparts. Therefore one goal in the field of targeted therapies is to develop chem. derivatized drugs or drug vectors able to target defined cells via specific recognition mechanisms and also able to overcome biol. barriers. This article will review the approaches which have been explored to achieve these goals and will discuss in more detail three examples (i) the use of nanostructures to take advantage of increased vascular permeability in some human diseases, (ii) the targeting of therapeutic drugs to an organ, the brain, protected against foreign mols. by the blood-brain barrier, and (iii) the use of the folate receptor to target either tumor cells or activated macrophages.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXot1GjsLk%253D&md5=3d0de63bde6c754668a05c9679678c78
    147. 147

Inhibitors of dipeptidyl peptidase 8 and dipeptidyl peptidase 9. Part 1: Identification of dipeptide derived leads Bioorg. Med. Chem. Lett. 2008, 18, 4154– 4158

      Potashman, M. H.; Duggan, M. E. Covalent modifiers: an orthogonal approach to drug design J. Med. Chem. 2009, 52, 1231– 1246
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      149
      Covalent Modifiers: An Orthogonal Approach to Drug Design
      Potashman, Michele H.; Duggan, Mark E.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 52 (5), 1231-1246CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. In this article we review a variety of examples in which therapeutic targets are covalently bound by small-mol. drugs or by compds. in advanced clin. development. The covalent interactions can be either reversible or irreversible, depending on the reaction partners.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhs1Sltbw%253D&md5=f8380d5a1cdd8638ad2a1e0405d25267
    150. 150
      Smith, A. J.; Zhang, X.; Leach, A. G.; Houk, K. N. Beyond picomolar affinities: quantitative aspects of noncovalent and covalent binding of drugs to proteins J. Med. Chem. 2009, 52, 225– 233
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      150
      Beyond picomolar affinities: quantitative aspects of noncovalent and covalent binding of drugs to proteins
      Smith, Adam J. T.; Zhang, Xiyun; Leach, Andrew G.; Houk, K. N.
      Journal of Medicinal Chemistry (2009), 52 (2), 225-233CODEN: JMCMAR; ISSN:0022-2623. (American Chemical Society)
      A review of 104 refs. summarized quant. aspects of noncovalent and covalent binding of drugs to proteins with subtopics including (1) introduction; (2) factors involved in ligand-recepto binding; (3) distribution of exptl. binding consts.; (3) covalent interactions with transition states as the origins of enzyme proficiency; (4) potential quant. advantages of covalent enzyme inhibitors and colent drugs; (5) selected examples of covalent inhibitors and drugs; (6) prospects for the design of covalent drugs; (7) conclusions.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      ARTICLE SECTIONS

      This article references 150 other publications.

      1. 1
        Rosenblum, J. S.; Kozarich, J. W. Prolyl peptidases: a serine protease subfamily with high potential for drug discovery Curr. Opin. Chem. Biol. 2003, 7, 496– 504
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        1
        Prolyl peptidases: a serine protease subfamily with high potential for drug discovery
        Rosenblum, Jonathan S.; Kozarich, John W.
        Current Opinion in Chemical Biology (2003), 7 (4), 496-504CODEN: COCBF4; ISSN:1367-5931. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        A review and discussion. Much attention has recently been given to a class of proteases that cleave proteins and peptides after Pro residues. This class includes esp. dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPP IV; also termed CD26) and fibroblast activation protein α (FAP; seprase), but also includes DPP7 (DPP II; quiescent cell proline dipeptidase), DPP8, DPP9, and prolyl carboxypeptidase (PCP; angiotensinase C). More distant members include prolyl oligopeptidase (POP; post-proline cleaving enzyme) and acylaminoacylpeptidase (AAP; acylpeptide hydrolase). The DPPs and related proteins contain both membrane-bound and sol. members and span a broad range of expression patterns, tissue distributions and compartmentalization. These proteins have important roles in regulation of signaling by peptide hormones, and are emerging targets for diabetes, oncol., and other indications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXmslemsrk%253D&md5=5c7d9bb0b121fd8d29c675270898b89f
      2. 2
        Polgár, L. The prolyl oligopeptidase family Cell. Mol. Life Sci. 2002, 59, 349– 362
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        2
        The prolyl oligopeptidase family
        Polgar, L.
        Cellular and Molecular Life Sciences (2002), 59 (2), 349-362CODEN: CMLSFI; ISSN:1420-682X. (Birkhaeuser Verlag)
        A review with 156 refs. A group of serine peptidases, the prolyl oligopeptidase family, cannot hydrolyze peptides contg. more than ∼30 residues. This group is unrelated to the classical trypsin and subtilisin families, and includes dipeptidyl peptidase IV, acylaminoacyl peptidase, and oligopeptidase B, in addn. to the prototype, prolyl oligopeptidase. The recent crystal structure detn. of prolyl oligopeptidase (80 kDa) has shown that the enzyme contains a peptidase domain with an α/β hydrolase fold, and its catalytic triad is covered by the central tunnel of an unusual 7-bladed β-propeller. This domain operates as a gating filter, excluding large, structured peptides from the active site. The binding mode of substrates and the catalytic mechanism differ from that of the classical serine peptidases in several features. The members of the family are important targets of drug design. Prolyl oligopeptidase is involved in amnesia, depression and blood pressure control, dipeptidyl peptidase IV in type 2 diabetes, and oligopeptidase B in trypanosomiasis.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XhvFKmtrk%253D&md5=10d172196f8959f7efcdc599fddc2e92
      3. 3
        Yaron, A.; Naider, F. Proline-dependent structural and biological properties of peptides and proteins Crit. Rev. Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1993, 28, 31– 81
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        3
        Proline-dependent structural and biological properties of peptides and proteins
        Yaron, Arieh; Naider, Fred
        Critical Reviews in Biochemistry and Molecular Biology (1993), 28 (1), 31-81CODEN: CRBBEJ; ISSN:1040-9238.
        A review, with 383 refs. Proline residues confer unique structural constraints on peptide chains and markedly influence the susceptibility of proximal peptide bonds to protease activity. A crit. anal. of peptidases involved in the cleavage of proline-contg. peptide bonds is presented, with particular attention to the role of proline peptidases in the regulation of the lifetime of biol. active peptides. Peptidases discussed include aminopeptidase P, prolidase, dipeptidyl peptidase IV, prolyl endopeptidase, and prolyl iminopeptidase. Attention is also given to HIV-1 protease, because this key enzyme processes an Xaa-Pro peptide bond.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3sXit1ylu70%253D&md5=67f47aa3fbe158ca0e236c7ba8665cde
      4. 4
        Männistö, P. T.; Venäläinen, J.; Jalkanen, A.; García-Horsman, J. A. Prolyl oligopeptidase: a potential target for the treatment of cognitive disorders Drug News Perspect. 2007, 20, 293– 306
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        4
        Prolyl oligopeptidase: a potential target for the treatment of cognitive disorders
        Mannisto, Pekka T.; Vanalainen, Jarkko; Jalkanen, Aaro; Garcia-Horsman, J. Arturo
        Drug News & Perspectives (2007), 20 (5), 293-305CODEN: DNPEED; ISSN:0214-0934. (Prous Science)
        A review. Prolyl oligopeptidase (POP) is a ubiquitous post-proline cleaving enzyme that is highly expressed in brain. Current knowledge about the biochem. features of POP and the pharmacol. action of its specific inhibitors has indicated that POP participates in several aspects of the central nervous system (CNS), including learning, memory and mood. Furthermore, a role has been suggested for POP in pathol. processes such as eating and mood disorders, hypertension and cell-cycle disturbances, in addn. to its proposed connection with the neurodegenerative processes which occur in Alzheimer's, Huntington's and Parkinson's diseases. The milestones responsible for the accelerated development of POP inhibitors include the discovery that these compds. reverse memory loss in animal models of drug- or lesion-induced amnesia and the observation that the expression of POP correlates with age. Today, several POP inhibitors have already been evaluated in preclin. trials as potential drugs for the treatment of natural memory deficits that occur with aging or the pathol. memory loss characteristic of Alzheimer's disease. Thus, the results that are emerging from basic research on POP function will facilitate the fine-tuning of more efficient drugs to target this protease.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXhtVKrtbjO&md5=90ad55b6e1ead99a5c702608f4ce327f
      5. 5
        Yoshimoto, T.; Kawahara, K.; Matsubara, F.; Kado, K.; Tsuru, D. Comparison of inhibitory effects of prolinal-containing peptide derivatives on prolyl endopeptidases from bovine brain and Flavobacterium J. Biochem. 1985, 98, 975– 979
        [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        5
        Comparison of inhibitory effects of prolinal-containing peptide derivatives on prolyl endopeptidases from bovine brain and Flavobacterium
        Yoshimoto, Tadashi; Kawahara, Kazuo; Matsubara, Futoshi; Kado, Kunio; Tsuru, Daisuke
        Journal of Biochemistry (1985), 98 (4), 975-9CODEN: JOBIAO; ISSN:0021-924X.
        The inhibitory effects of proline-contg. peptides and their derivs. on prolyl endopeptidases from F. meningosepticum and bovine brain were compared. Replacement of the C-terminal proline in N-blocked peptides with prolinal resulted in remarkable decreases in the Ki values for both prolyl endopeptidases. Further redn. of prolinal to prolinol led to a decrease in their inhibitory effects. Benzyloxycarbonyl (Z)-prolyl-, Z-valyl, and succinylprolyl-prolinals were similarly inhibitory for both the enzymes with Ki values of the nanomolar order. However, the inhibitory effects of Z-pyroglutamyl-prolinal and tert-butoxycarbonylprolyl-prolinal on these enzymes were significantly different: they strongly inhibited mammalian prolyl endopeptidase with Ki values of the nanomolar order, whereas the Ki values of these compds. for the microbial enzyme were only of the micromolar order. Thus, there are some structural differences in the S2 and S3 subsites between the 2 enzymes, though their substrate specificities are apparently indistinguishable.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaL28Xis1Gl&md5=f1b171be4745b7b837e2892453d4feff
      6. 6
        Saito, M.; Hashimoto, M.; Kawaguchi, N.; Fukami, H.; Tanaka, T.; Higuchi, N. Synthesis and inhibitory activity of acyl-peptidyl-prolinal derivatives toward post-proline cleaving enzyme as nootropic agents J. Enzyme Inhib. 1990, 3, 163– 178
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6
        Synthesis and inhibitory activity of acyl-peptidyl-prolinal derivatives toward post-proline cleaving enzyme as nootropic agents
        Saito, Masayuki; Hashimoto, Masaki; Kawaguchi, Naoko; Fukami, Harukazu; Tanaka, Takaharu; Higuchi, Naoki
        Journal of Enzyme Inhibition (1990), 3 (3), 163-78CODEN: ENINEG; ISSN:8755-5093.
        Several prolinal derivs. were synthesized and examd. for their inhibitory activity on postproline-cleaving enzyme (EC 3.4.21.26) from Flavobacterium meningosepticum and bovine brain and their possible properties as nootropic agents. Almost all compds. tested inhibited the activity of both enzymes at low IC50 values in the nanomolar range, but a specificity difference was obsd. with alkylacyl-prolinal derivs. which strongly inhibited only the bacterial enzyme. Prolyl-prolinal derivs. were the most effective inhibitors for both enzymes. In the passive avoidance test using amnesic rats exptl. induced with scopolamine, the prolinal derivs. that have potent inhibitory activity toward postproline-cleaving enzymes showed also strong anti-amnesic activities at doses of 10-1000 μg/kg, i.p. Some of the compds. showed a bell-shape dose dependency. These results suggest that the postproline cleaving enzymes play an important role in the regulation of learning and memory consolidation in the brain and inhibitors of these enzymes are suggested as possible candidates for nootropic agents, particularly for an anti-amnesic drug.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXktF2qtr0%253D&md5=9b0b44635102bf2fffb17e51171b1b84
      7. 7
        Santana, J. M.; Grellier, P.; Schrével, J.; Teixeira, A. R. L. A Trypanosoma cruzi-secreted 80 kDa proteinase with specificity for human collagen types I and IV Biochem. J. 1997, 325, 129– 137
        Google Scholar
